rationale: No intensifier or comparative directly modifies a risk-adjective.
statement_text: The World Health Organization (WHO), in a reply to Reuters in Geneva, said: "The source of the patient’s exposure to the H10N3 virus is not known at this time, and no other cases were found in emergency surveillance among the local population."

rationale: The language is factual reporting of status and outcome, lacking high-potency verbs or metaphors.
statement_text: The World Health Organization (WHO), in a reply to Reuters in Geneva, said: "The source of the patient’s exposure to the H10N3 virus is not known at this time, and no other cases were found in emergency surveillance among the local population."

rationale: The segment uses plain outcome verbs ('said', 'found') and indicates low scale ('no other cases').
statement_text: The World Health Organization (WHO), in a reply to Reuters in Geneva, said: "The source of the patient’s exposure to the H10N3 virus is not known at this time, and no other cases were found in emergency surveillance among the local population."

rationale: The segment does not contain a loaded rhetorical question.
statement_text: The World Health Organization (WHO), in a reply to Reuters in Geneva, said: "The source of the patient’s exposure to the H10N3 virus is not known at this time, and no other cases were found in emergency surveillance among the local population."

rationale: This reports unknown source and absence of other cases (positive facts) but lacks explicit calming language.
statement_text: The World Health Organization (WHO), in a reply to Reuters in Geneva, said: "The source of the patient’s exposure to the H10N3 virus is not known at this time, and no other cases were found in emergency surveillance among the local population."

rationale: 'not known' and 'no other cases were found' are bare negations, not minimiser + scale contrast.
